awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology: The Eco-Evolutionary Tradeoffs of Aggregative Multicellularity
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2022, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. This research will advance understanding of how complex life has evolved. Many living organisms, including plants and animals, depend on cooperative interactions between many cells that carry out specific and important functions. These complex organisms are referred to as multicellular. In contrast, other organisms have remained unicellular and do not depend on cooperative cellular interactions to persist. Previous research suggests complex multicellularity has not evolved for some organisms because cells choose to act selfishly rather than cooperate with one another. The conditions that favor and inhibit the evolution and persistence of cooperative multicellular interactions remains an outstanding question in the field of evolutionary biology. This research will address this knowledge gap by determining the conditions under which more complex organisms evolve. Addressing this question is important to improving our understanding of how multicellular life arose on Earth, and why there is so much variation in multicellular complexity across the tree of life. The Fellow will mentor students from underrepresented groups in research as well as through public outreach activities. 

This research will test the hypothesis that integration in aggregative multicellular organisms is limited by an eco-evolutionary trade-off: unstable environments favor social generalism, which limits the evolution of genotype-specific multicellular integration. The research will use synthetic biology to generate a laboratory model system of aggregative multicellularity, engineering the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae to require obligate metabolic cross-feeding. Aggregative yeast will be experimentally coevolved to examine how the fidelity of their mutualistic partners affects the evolution of genotype-genotype specialization. The ecological implications of specialization will then be assessed by testing for fitness tradeoffs associated with specialists and generalists. These results will be placed in a broader context by using a theoretical model to evaluate the effect of environmental heterogeneity on the evolution of multicellularity. The Fellow predicts that increased complexity will evolve when there are increased opportunities for specialization between coevolved cells. Fellow training includes metabolomics, microscopy, and mathematical modeling at Georgia Tech. The Fellow will also broaden participation in science by mentoring first-generation and low-income undergraduates in scientific research and by developing hands-on scientific activities for underrepresented elementary school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Complex life has evolved through a series of key innovations, referred to as major evolutionary transitions. These transitions occur through the cooperation and integration of previously autonomous organisms. Evolutionary transitions mark a pivotal shift where the primary unit of natural selection moves from the lower-level traits of the cooperative ancestors to the traits of the collective. Theory predicts these transitions require high genetic relatedness between partners. This limits the potential for social conflict, making selection more likely to act on collective-level traits. Consistent with this, mechanisms that limit genetic diversity are common across organisms considered functionally integrated. Yet, many evolutionary transitions have occurred between organisms involving genetically distinct partners (i.e., eukaryogenesis and heritable symbiosis), demonstrating that genetic heterogeneity does not necessarily preclude these transitions. Why then have evolutionary transitions remained constrained for so many cooperative interactions?

I tested the hypothesis that evolutionary transitions involving heterogenous partners are constrained by eco-evolutionary tradeoffs. I predicted that integration most likely occurs when partners that have opportunities for reciprocal evolutionary change across generations (e.g., coevolution), allowing them to become increasingly specialized to one another. However, specialization is only beneficial in stable environments where partners are readily accessible, and it is likely to be disfavored in unstable environments where repeated interactions between partners are unlikely. In these environments, generalists, capable of interacting with a broad range of partners, gain an advantage. Therefore, whether an evolutionary transition occurs may depend on the selective environment.

I tested this hypothesis using genetically engineered strains of mutualistically cross-feeding Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Strains were engineered so that one strain was auxotrophic for tryptophan and overproduced leucine (Trp-Leu+; ‘Strain A’), and the other was auxotrophic for leucine and overproduced tryptophan (Trp+Leu-; ‘Strain B’). The mutualistic strains were experimentally evolved under selection for mutualism by passaging on agar plates lacking leucine and tryptophan. In the High Partner Fidelity (HPF) treatment, Strain A and Strain B were synchronously co-passaged, creating opportunities for coevolution and specialization. In the Low Partner Fidelity A (LPF-A) treatment, the Trp-Leu+ Strain A continually evolved and was co-passaged with three serially rotating isogenic Trp+Leu- Mutualistic Partner B strains (MP-B1, MP-B2, and MP-B3), and in the Low Partner Fidelity B (LPF-B) treatment the Trp+Leu- Strain B was co-passaged with three serially rotating isogenic Trp-Leu+ A strains (MP-A1, MP-A2, and MP-A3). This provided the opportunity for multi-partner coevolution but inhibited specialization. In the Control treatment, Trp-Leu+ and Trp+Leu- strains evolved independently on media containing all necessary amino acids. Each treatment was independently replicated five times.

After 54 passages (270 days of selection), increased fitness benefits (increased growth) only evolved in the HPF treatment, and strains from both LPF treatments gained no increase in fitness compared to the controls . Strains from both the HPF and LPF-A treatments exhibited higher fitness when paired with their co-passaged partner relative by being paired with the ancestor, demonstrating selection acted on the interactions. However, strains from the LPF-B treatment exhibited no fitness advantage when paired with their co-passaged partner versus the ancestor, suggesting weak selection on the interaction. For the HPF treatment, I tested for specialization by assessing whether sympatric strain combinations (sharing a coevolutionary history) exhibited higher fitness than allopatric combinations (no coevolutionary history). I observed no evidence for specialization between sympatric strains. This may suggest that co-passaging did not result in specialization through coevolution. Alternatively, co-passaged partners may have become more specialized through coevolution, but I could not detect specialization using this approach because replicate lineages evolved along similar evolutionary trajectories.

Intellectual Merit: This work addresses a central challenge in the field of evolutionary biology: the mechanisms facilitating and constraining evolutionary transitions. It tested the hypothesis that the environment can alter opportunities for evolutionary transitions and provided evidence supporting this hypothesis. Increased fitness benefits only evolved when partners had opportunities for coevolution. Evolutionary transitions may be more likely to occur in interactions with limited genetic diversity because this creates sustained opportunities for coevolution. In addition, these results demonstrated that evolving under selection from multiple mutualistic partners can constrain mutualistic rewards.  As such, this work provides unique insights relevant to researchers studying both mutualism and evolutionary transitions across scales. I have presented this work at several invited seminars, three conferences, and it will soon be published.

Broader Impacts: During my PRFB fellowship, I developed a Georgia Pre-K outreach program focusing on cooperative interactions. I partnered with a Pre-K program located in downtown Atlanta and primarily serving underrepresented students in STEM. The students learned about cooperative interactions between microbes, observed bioluminescent microbes, and merged science with art to paint their own glow-in-the-dark microbes. I also served as a mentor to three women researchers, including two undergraduates and a graduate student. By supporting my independent research, this fellowship also enabled me to receive a position as a tenure-track professor at an R1 academic institution.
